snippet.textDisplay: @hawks9nkh That would actually be VERY easy to prove otherwise if they had access to your sewage. 1. You're not going to always be having a party, and sewage is a flow, so it's as simple as getting data from different days. 2. Your sewage is unique to you based on your biology and what you've eaten recently. Getting sewage from multiple people would be very obvious if they're analyzing it. 3. They easily can access your water usage records. If there's no spike in usage, there was no party.
snippet.textOriginal: @hawks9nkh That would actually be VERY easy to prove otherwise if they had access to your sewage. 1. snippet.textDisplay:
@cgi2002 Yeah, that's why I kept emphasizing that they were lowball, very rough numbers. There are so many things I can't possibly know yet about it that I can only ballpark it with existing services that do some key aspects of it.

And on top of that I'm outright assuming they can make a sewage plumbing insert device that safely allows injection of chemicals into a testing chamber. I know the cartridge deployment mechanism would work, but a chemical or biological test that can be conducted on a small sample of the liquid component of raw sewage and read with some kind of sensor that can be protected from the sewage...that's another matter. I know certain things CAN be tested that way and others can't, and it could well be that anything a politician would want to test is in the "can't" pile.

As a side note, though, this wouldn't need PPE with how I'm envisioning it for the cartridge system. The cartridge would be a bit like an inkjet cartridge with a nozzle interface to the device and a liquid inside. The device would have a mechanism for pumping a controlled amount out of the cartridge also like with an inkjet, and this would go into a waiting chamber. The waiting chamber would be entrance-sealed, flushed into a mixing chamber, then exit-sealed. The mixing chamber would then have a sample of the sewage flushed in through a similar system and then it would flow into a scanning chamber where the machine would read the results. Then the mixing chamber and scanning chamber would be flushed. The cartridge would just be empty when replaced.

I'm using the inkjet cartridge for an easy example of how it works, but I'm actually basing my idea on some IoT COVID testing machines that do something similar, but involving putting a sample in a tube, and for a LOT more money per use.

But again, an enormous amount of assumptions built into this.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Merennulli waste management is much quicker per house too. Each house averages about 20 seconds as your cans must be right near the street or they'll ignore them. Alot of homes use sewage lines that tend to run along a main that may be in the back of a garden or underneath a basement. So to access them your looking at much closer to several minutes per household. Don't know if you worked this into your math, but that said garbage trucks also tend to have 3-5 staff so it may average out if the swaps are on average about 2mins.

Also I skipped a cost, maintenance. Units will from time to time need fully replacing (hopefully that can be done via the access thats been built for the refills), and occasionally there will be collapsed access pipes, or if the access pipe is on public land, overgrowth. 

Then you also need to plan for PPE costs, garbage men tend not to be sticking their hands in the garbage. Also the PPE would need to be replaced/cleaned between properties to avoid cross contamination on the refills and thus invalidating any results of value. Could also argue under this that these would be sewer workers and not refuse, I doubt they'll work for the same wages as refuse workers. 

When you really start to dig into this, it becomes a much more complex project than at first glance. Installing it in an existing location would be exceptionally expensive, however doing it during the construction of a neighbourhood were you can set up central sewage hubs it would be far cheaper (been able to open 1 manhole and change 10-20 at a time).

snippet.textDisplay: @cgi2002 The $25/mo was for government employees or contractors going door to door swapping cartridges. I based it off current waste management services (garbage services) which already includes significant waste management. But yes, I didn't figure in installation cost which would likely annualize around 800 by itself.
snippet.textOriginal: @cgi2002 The $25/mo was for government employees or contractors going door to door swapping cartridges. I based it off current waste management services (garbage services) which already includes significant waste management. But yes, I didn't figure in installation cost which would likely annualize around 800 by itself.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Merennulli of your estimate which I admit was impressive your missing 3 major costs. 
First is disposal of used refills, that's what should be deemed hazardous waste that should not be disposed of in the general waste. So alongside your general waste you now need a bio waste service.
Second is delivery of the refills, that's going to probably cost more in postage than the kit actually costs to produce.
Third and finally, ensuring the refills are installed. You'd find it nigh impossible to legislate that homeowners must do this, best you can do is legislate that they can't tamper with the IoT setups to begin with. Just like utility meters, the homeowner isn't responsible for their maintenance, but must provide unobstructed access to them.
So now you need an employee to come out and fit the refills, and across a city that going to take a few hundred/thousand people a day.
Oh and remember these sensors need surface access, so you need to physically dig access shafts for all of them and fit an adaptor to the sewage lines that doesn't leak, probably on public footpaths, or along property boundaries, definatly not inside the property itself due to how often access is needed. That alone will cost more than the rest of the project combined.

Third and finally, ensuring the refills are installed.
